36864.name: Naked!
36864.description: From the manufacturer: Naked! has the same values and suits as a regular poker deck, but printed on each card is an article of clothing. Play your favorite poker games. When you win, you get to assign cards from your winning hand to other players. Players who receive cards have to remove the clothing that is pictured on the card. The winner is the last player remaining who is not Naked!

36865.description:
From the manufacturer:

Anything you can do, I can do BETTER! Chalenj! Is the all thinking, all action activity game that brings out the competitive side in everyone!! Can you name more US States than your sister? Can you beat your best friend at singing Madonna songs? Find out by racing around the Chalenj! board, chalenjing each other to be the best in four separate categories. If one player decides to Chalenj another, the glove is slapped down on the table and the fun begins. Ages 8 and up. For 2 to 6 players or teams.
36865.name: Chalenj

36866.name: Link-O
36866.description:
From the manufacturer:

Link-O is the fun, challenging numbers game that will have you turning in circles! Place tiles end to end on the board by matching the numbers and color on each tile, as you try to be the first to play all of your tiles. The tiles left over in your opponent's possession are totaled as points for YOU. It's all-around fun with numbers for the whole family! Includes 64 tiles, tile bag, game board and instructions in English and Spanish. For 2 to 6 Players. Ages 5 and up.

36867.name: Scooby Doo Pop 'N' Race Game
36867.description: A 2 to 4 player racing game Ages 5 and up. Race to be the first player to get all four of your movers to the finish. Comes with a colorful plastic game board with a dice popper in the center, and 16 movers.

36868.name: Ben 10 Omnitrix Duel for Power Game
36868.description:
From the manufacturer:

Go head to head against your opponent as you try to collect the most alien cards and win. The Omnitrix tells you whether you want to have the lower or the higher card during each battle. Achieve that and you add both cards to your win pile. Special cards tie the battle up and bring another, more powerful battle on!

36869.name: Suite Life Double the Fun Card Game
36869.description: Turn up cards for points until you decide to stop and you keep your points for that turn. If you keep going, you wager the amount of points you have accumulated and push your luck to gain more with each card you turn up. If you turn up a Moseby, you lose all the points you gained for that turn, UNLESS you get a Joker Zack, which makes you immune to Moseby. Collect pairs of Zack and Cody cards for extra points. The player with the most points when the cards run out is the winner.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Vuoden Peli Children's Game of the Year Nominee
36870.name: Haisuli vei
36870.description:
Contents: 4 double-sided playing pieces, 4 6-piece sturdy cardboard puzzles, a bell (ála Halli Galli), gaming board, a die.

Each player represents a pair of Moomin characters. Players are trying to build a boat by collecting 6 pieces of their puzzle. Each player starts from their own corner of the board. During your turn you roll a six-sided die and move your gaming piece clockwise around the gameboard. 1st player to collect all six pieces and get back to their starting corner sails to the lighthouse island for search of a hidden treasure.

Players get pieces for their puzzles during their own turn when they pass their starting corner or when they hit a location depicting a happy sun on the board and their gaming piece also shows a happy sun. When player hits a location that shows different sun than their gaming piece at the moment, their piece is flipped over (happy/sad).

It is possible to get a piece of the puzzle during someone elses turn: The die has numbers from 1 to 5. One side has a picture of "Haisuli" eg. Stinky. Whenever this side comes up, whoever is first to hit the bell in the middle of the board (at the lighthouse island) grabs a extra piece for their puzzle.

Also, it is possible to lose already collected puzzle pieces when you hit a sad sun and your gaming piece also shows a sad sun or when you hit another players starting corner.

Game of The Year 2007 Childrens Game finalist in Finland.

36871.name: Solairis
36871.description: Players are one representative of the seven races of the Solairis system. They duel using spells that are powered by power cards. When one has lost the last hit point they lose. If you run out of power cards the spells are reshuffled and a new hand of spell and power cards are dealt.

36872.name: Firaapeli
36872.description: A Scrabble-like word game designed and published by an advertising agency for using as a gift to their customers. You are using nine letters, there are no tripling options, doubling options are scarce and there are some extra bonuses available. The rules are constantly making fun of the advertisement world.

36873.name: Hell's Foxes
36873.description:
Hells Foxes is a board game of the North African Campaign of World War II conducted between the Axis forces of Germany and Italy and the Allied forces of United Kingdom - England, Australia, New Zealand, India, South Africa, France, Poland, Jewish Battalion, from the Spring of 1941 until the winter of 1942.
COMPONENTS


1 "Rules Book" consisting with a Light BLUE 'cover' which contains some "Errata", and inside 16 pages of "Rules", while the BACK 'cover' has some "Charts" and other *Notes*.
4 Paper MAPS 11 X 16 Black on White printed with "Graphic" renditions displaying the "Terrain" from its 'genre' for "WW-2 North Africa Campaigns" at the time of publication. Adjoin these in correct 'order' from 1 to 4 and secure properly, such as with taping it down, or placing "perspex" / "plexiglas" for that.
3 Small Label Sheets with Front & Back images comprising:
(1) of RED print for "Axis"
(1) of BLUE print for "Allied"
(1) of GREEN print for BOTH to use as "Game Markers".

36874.name: Valley of the Dinosaurs
36874.description: A spin and move board game for Ages 7 - 12. Comes with cardboard cutout players, spinner, board, and rules. Based on the Hanna-Barbera cartoon series of the same name. The object of the game is to help the Butler family make it safely across the valley to the caves.

36875.name: El Tesoro Escondido
36875.description: In this children's game, the players must reach the treasure by throwing the dice and moving on the board. During journey they will find dangers such as the giant octopus, the dungeon of doom, the infected rats and the great volcano. They should avoid these risks to get the treasure trove and win.

36876.name: El Listón de MARCA
36876.description:
El listón de MARCA is a game for most athletes and for those who know most of all about sports. It can be played by up to 5 teams of one or more players. The aim is to build the word "MARCA" with a letter of each color. This requires successfully responding to questions in every major category using the boxes provided for this purpose. During the game the players will answer several questions about the world of sports to reach the main squares where they obtain letters of different colors (tokens).

This game is a fun game for the entire family and especially for sports fans in general. The game system is based on Trivia games.

MARCA is currently the best-selling sports daily in Spain and designed this game in 1997 for sale along with the newspaper for several weeks.

36877.description:
The Romulan Ship Recognition Manual expands on the ships types seen in the base game Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator, adding new variants for almost every Romulan ship in that product, as well as adding a number of new craft.

As with the base Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator itself, this is ostensibly an "expansion" for the Role Playing game, in that it provides more data than just the combat element requires. 3-dimension views are provided for all craft, along with extensive historical notes and background.

The book was released with two covers, each with the same internal info. In both cases, the cover of this 48-page product features a cutaway of the Romulan 'Whitewind' cruiser. However, the first release version has only the words "ROMULAN SHIP RECOGNITION MANUAL" in red block letters on the cover, while the second version has the "framed" design shared with the 2nd Edition Federation & Klingon SRMs.

Indicating the clear tie to the wargame, the last page presents a sheet of counters that you can photocopy and mount on cardboard for use with the tactical game.

Expands:

Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator
36877.name: Romulan Ship Recognition Manual

36878.name: Le tri sélectif
36878.description:
The goal of this game is to score a maximum of points by playing cards representing recyclable and non recyclable wastes.
A recyclable waste is composed of two cards, and hence is worth two points.
A non recyclable waste is only represented by a single card, and is therefore only worth one point.
This is an educational game which aims at helping to distinguish recyclables wastes from non recyclable ones.

36879.name: Pizza Bake-Off
36879.description: Players attempt to complete pizza recipes by collecting different resources from various places in the kitchen. Movement is done using addition and subtraction cards to move to various spaces - which reward the player with a topping or a special card they can use. The board is two-sided, so that players can play with single or double-digit addition.

36881.description:
A regular Anno Domini set consists of 336 cards, with a description of a historical event on one side of the card, and the year (and sometimes specific date) in which it happened on the other.

This small expansion set Anno Domini - Probespiel was a free giveaway by the publisher. It only contains about 8-15 event cards without a common theme. Since this is not enough for a real game, it only comes with a brief summary of the gameplay.

Each player receives nine of these cards (or less, if you want the game to be shorter), and may only look at the descriptions. Players then put in turn a card on the table, *trying* to put theirs in chronological order. A player may, instead of adding a card, claim that the order in which the cards were put is incorrect. In this case all cards are turned over and the correct years revealed.
If the order was correct then the doubting player receives two cards and skips a turn. If the order was incorrect then the previous player, who accepted the order as correct, receives three cards. The first player that gets rid of all the cards wins.

Bluffing is as least as important as knowledge in this game. Most events are rather obscure or are hard to date exactly. Anno Domini is a blast to play, it is a very enjoyable social event and you even learn something from it.

Part of the Anno Domini series

Contained as a free bonus in this German version of Such a Thing?, this German version of Zooloretto and this German version of Airlines Europe.
36881.name: Anno Domini: Probespiel

36882.description:
The Klingon Ship Recognition Manual expands on the ships types seen in the base game Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator, adding new variants for almost every Klingon ship in that product, as well as adding a number of new fighters, ships, and bases.

As with the base Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator itself, this is ostensibly an "expansion" for the Role Playing game, in that it provides more data than just the combat element requires. 3-dimension views are provided for all craft, along with extensive historical notes and background. The cover of this 48-page product features a cutaway of the Klingon D-20 'Deathrite' cruiser.

Indicating the clear tie to the wargame, the last page presents a sheet of counters that you can photocopy and mount on cardboard for use with the tactical game.

Expands

Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator
36882.name: Klingon Ship Recognition Manual

36883.name: Friday Night Fights
36883.description:
"YOU CAN RUN BUT YOU CAN'T HIDE."

A twenty-foot square ring doesn’t give you much room to move and definitely nowhere to hide. Boxing - it’s called the “Sweet Science” for a reason. You can move around your opponent flicking jabs and dancing away. “Rope a dope” and pick your spots firing punches and scoring points. All that skillful stuff, putting on a boxing clinic and looking pretty while you’re doing it. Then.... BOOM!
Your opponent throws a hook from downtown and “out go the lights!”

Friday Night Fights is unlike any boxing game you've ever played. With FNF you can... Build your fighter the way you want him. Boxer or slugger it's all up to you.

Fight your way to the title through 36 pre-generated fighters that are run by the game mechanics.
Become a promoter with your own fighters. Train them and pick and choose your opponents on your way to the top.




Everything you need to start your own “fight club” with your friends is included. It’s an exciting game where you have to think as you fight. Do you go “all out” as soon as the bell rings? Or maybe pace yourself for the full fight? And what’s he doing?

Do you have the heart of a Champion? Only you can tell. Friday Night Fights – “Play to win…”

36884.description:
The Federation Ship Recognition Manual expands on the ships types seen in the base game Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator, adding new variants for every Federation ship in that product, including new shuttles, starships, freighters, and starbases.

As with the base Star Trek: Starship Tactical Combat Simulator itself, this is ostensibly an "expansion" for the Role Playing game, in that it provides more data than just the combat element requires. 3-dimension views are provided for all craft, along with extensive historical notes and background. The cover of this 42-page product features a cutaway of the Federation 'Remora' escort craft.

No counters are provides with this product, however, the last page is a fold-out diagram showing a time line of the service lifetimes of the various ship classes, as well as silhouettes of all ships showing relative sizes.
36884.name: Federation Ship Recognition Manual

36885.name: Sauve Qui Peut
36885.description:
From 1790 to 1815 Europe was at war with itself and dragged most of the rest of the world with it. The Napoleonic Wars are Earth’s first true World War. England and France had colonies all around the planet. Many of the other nations entered the fray. Most note worthy was the War of 1812, the USA v Great Britain.

SQP is a chance for players to take one of the armies of the
combatants into one of the large battles that denoted combat for that period. Experienced players can easily maneuver 40 or more battalions. The rules are historical and designed for a medium degree of difficulty. Veteran gamers will feel comfortable after a walk through. Players new to gaming will be able to compete after their first game.

SQP is designed for two to six players to enjoy a three hour game.

Armies list for the 17 major European nation, the Ottomans and
Americans are included.

36886.name: The Battle of Sharpsburg
36886.description:
This is a tactical simulation of the American Civil War battle near Sharpsburg on 17 September 1862. The components include:
1 8x10 map
1 set of rules 2.5 pages long including charts & tables
1 set of 26 counters; 10 Union, 15 Confederate & 1 game turn

The Union Infantry are Corps-sized, the Confederate Infantry are Division-sized. No scale is given for distance on the map or for each (of the 10) turns. Mechanics are a simple yugo-igo, but rough terrain and ample artillery make things interesting.

Original images are provided, as well as some graphically-updated images.

This is a good example of what early DTP-like self-publishing could do. Remember ... 1975 ... 33 years ago.

boardgamehonor: 2009 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
36887.description:
Description courtesy of BoardgameNews.com

Waterloo – a two-player game for early 2009 with the French and British fighting once again. The action system is a clever creation: You know the range of possible actions that you can take on a turn, but the opponent knows exactly how many actions you have, and that knowledge strips the certainty from your preparation. Can you get your infantry back in a defensive position before the opponent thunders through with his cavalry? If you don’t think you can, you might develop timidly, which gives the opponent a better shot of taking valuable terrain.

Damage in the game is represented by blue/red/black cubes, and you can distribute the cubes throughout your lines during the game to represent the movement of troops back and forth from the front lines. Shifting all the damage to the back seems like a no-brainer, but if cavalry does break through your front line, your troops are toast. Morale is checked only in face-to-face combat, and it’s handled by a die roll compared with the level of damage within an area.

Control of areas like La Haye Sainte is critical. Just as Wellington tried to funnel French attacks through gaps in ridges in order to cut off their support, you can do the same, fighting for highland to prevent being pinched. The French win if they take Mont St. Jean, the British if they take Rosonne; if neither occurs before the end of 8pm (ie the last turn), then the British and Allies win.
36887.name: Waterloo
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 39: Martin Wallace
Meeples & Miniatures - Episode #50

36888.description:
Description courtesy of BoardgameNews.com

After the Flood – a three-player game that’s set in Sumeria, with players using regional resources to trade for goods not produced in the area while also building short-lived empires for long-lasting victory points.

“Certain mechanisms were created with three players in mind,” says Wallace. “You score an empire, then remove it, so you can try to maximize points on your turn without leaving yourself in a position to get hit on following turns.” This design sidesteps the problem of a third player winning a game due to fights to the death by players 1 and 2, but that bug becomes a feature in another part of the game. Competition among the players for goods and army strength is relative rather than linear; having twice as many dudes collecting resources won’t net you twice the number of goods, so getting into an arms race with one opponent might hurt the two of you together and advantage the third player who can spend resources on better things.

Controlling different cities gives you different bonuses, with the bonus being based on the history of the city itself: Sippar lets you trade more, Babylon counts for additional armies, and so forth. Combat in the game is dice-based to avoid deterministic battles in which you can guarantee victory simply by piling up more troops, although size does have its advantages.



Game Summary
Like Wallace's other games Liberté and Byzantium, players don't represent a particular faction/nation. Instead, the game covers a long period of history (~1500 years in this case) and players temporarily control empires as they rise and fall. Score VP at the end of each turn (~350 years) when the empires fall. Players start with several resources and 2 workers in their available stock, and workers in the irrigation and weaving boxes. Each turn follows the same steps:1. Collect Resources (grain and textiles) based on relative rank of workers in the irrigation/weaving. Then take 8 workers to available stock (total 10 at start of game). Move all workers in Scribes and Toolmakers to the left (and "Unused") side.

2. Decline (turns 2 and 4 ONLY): each player removes all workers from Dilmun, and 1 from every non-Sumerian region. In the Irrigation and Weaving boxes, the player with the most workers reduces their number TO 2 (with n being the number of workers they returned to supply). The other players remove n workers. Finally, each removes 1 worker from the Scribes and Toolmakers boxes.

3. Player Actions. In turn order (random at start of game), take 1 action. If anyone has passed, you must discard one item (resource, worker, or army) from your available stock to take an action. Continue rotating in turn order till all 3 pass. Action Choices:
- Build City. Place one of your city markers in Sumerian region with no other city there. Most give you a special power. If all 4 out, may destroy old city to build new one.
- Place Workers. Spend a resource of value x; place up to x workers in ONE location (Scribe box: max 2 workers/player). In addition, or instead, may use each unused scribe to move or place a worker.
- Trade. Each worker is allowed to trade 1 resource for 1 of the resource(s) available in their region. Each region only provides 1 of each resource present there. However, if ANY army is in the region, workers cannot do anything. Each army, though, can conduct 1 trade just like a worker. In addition, or instead, you can use worker(s) in the Toolmakers box to convert metal to Tools (1/worker).
- Start Empire. 3 available each turn, 1/player. Each has designated start region (2 Sumerian empires -- may start anywhere in Sumer). You must have equal or greater number of workers than any other single player in their home region (except Sumerian empires: no workers needed). Take designated # armies into available stock; may buy more (pay resource(s)). Also, may equip (spend resources; rank by value relative to what other already created empires spent). Then come onto board: if enemy army there, fight. Otherwise (or once enemy killed), place 1 or 2 armies in starting region.
- Expand Empire.
... Place Army token (from available stock) to adjacent region. If enemy army present, fight.
... Destroy City. If have army in region with enemy city, discard 2 from supply to destroy it -- return to supply.
... Reinforce Region: place 2nd army into a region (max 2/region).
... After any choice above, may discard 1 army from supply to Expand again.
Fighting
Attacker rolls 2d6. If better equipped than defender, kills on 5+. Otherwise, need 7+. May continue attacking until decide to end battle, or win and place 1 army in new region (all considered 1 attack; i.e., don't need to discard an army to continue the fight).
- Pass. May opt to discard resource(s) as well.

4. Determine Turn Order. Based on resources discarded when passing: most-->least first-->third. If tied, retain relative turn order.

5. Score VP. 2VP/region with your army token. Then in turn order, decide whether or not to improve your cities: each requires discarding 2 wood + 0-4 resources (earn 3-18 VP). If improved, place marker on city -- it won't score again.

6. Reset. Remove all armies from board. Remove all armies and workers from available stock. Advance turn marker.

End of Game
- After end of turn 5.
- Final scoring: player with most workers in each region scores VP shown on board.
- Most VP wins. Tiebreaker = turn order.
36888.name: After the Flood
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 31: Three player games

36889.name: Numeralogic
36889.description: Players attempt to guess other players' secret number in the fewest number of turns through a combination of luck and logic. The game can be played by selecting anywhere from 2-5 digits depending on the time available and the ability of the players. Numeralogic is similar to Mastermind except each player selects a secret number and guessing alternates.

36890.name: Speedway Racing
36890.description:
(from their website)

Calling All Race Fans
CATCH THE EXCITEMENT OF "BIG TIME AUTO RACING"!

If you love stock car racing, you must play Speedway Racing's board game. The Speedway Racing board game gives you 'big time stock car auto racing' and 'live event track action' for true, behind the wheel racing experiences.

At the Drivers Meeting, you will receive your Drivers Handbook and will learn the rules of the race.
With one to five drivers, choose your favorite car, then 'start your engines'. Drivers race their cars around the oval track based on a roll of the dice. There are Bonus Points in the game. If you are lucky enough to roll doubles or other combinations imprinted, on the Speedway Racing game board, you will accelerate your advancement around the track.

During the Driver's meeting, you also learn that this will be a fast paced, five-lap competition. You will be driving against other highly competitive opponents. There are many Challenges and Pitfalls ahead of you as you speed around the track to take your car, to the coveted "Winner Circle", of Speedway Racing's board game.

Before you begin, choose Option 1, for the first driver to cross the finish line. Or, Option 2, in case all drivers are 'stacked up' and trying to cross the finish line. One last roll of the dice will determine the winner. You must choose Option 1 or Option 2, before the race begins.

The Race is Underway! Of course, the object of the game is to win the race, but beware; there are advantages and obstacles as you thunder around the track.

Hit the "Pit Stop" Zone or the "Speedway Challenge" Zone and adjust your position based on the events of each opportunity. Hit the wall and you suffer the consequences, in your quest. If you can avoid an accident, you will advance your position on the track.

Take care in selecting your pit crew. Many track advantages will depend on the timing, action and reaction speed of your pit crew.A driver can pilot the race car, but the pit crew will make the crucial difference in the outcome of the victory.

As in real speedway racing, your pit crew is vital! The Speedway Racing Board Game track graphics are beautifully illustrated. The game's race cars are authentic 1:144 scale die-cast metal with moving wheels.

The "Challenge" cards and "Pit Stop" cards are
realistic 'during the race' events. As you position your car and maneuver around the track, you will encounter cars hitting the wall, track debris, flat tires and yellow flags.

Caution Flags Are Out! Beware of Hazards!!

White-knuckle rookie drivers could hit the car in front of them, have stalled engines or make serious driving errors, while lapped traffic slows you down. The events of the "Speedway Racing" board game will impact the sheer adrenaline rush of moving forward, as you concentrate, on the coveted first place win. As you cross the Finish Line, move your car into the "Winner's Circle".

Each game contains a highly detailed graphic game board, five 1:144 scale die-cast cars with moving wheels, drivers challenge cards, dice and directions, in a re-usable bag. Family board game enthusiasts may want to have multiple games for their weekly or monthly family board game night.

The rules, of this family board game, are easy enough for the youngest race fans, but challenging enough, to keep you and the other drivers ever watchful on the track.

Home Page: http://www.speedwayracing.net/

36891.name: Mutação
36891.description:
One player plays is the mutant and can become any object in the environment in which they play. The others players have to discover the color, shape and position of the mutant.
The mutant can only answer the questions with yes or no.

36892.name: Aventura no Mar
36892.description:
Adventure at Sea.

Meet the pirates and recover the treasure of King!

In this game, one player is the adventurer, who needs to find the Island of Treasure, the other player is the pirate, who hides the treasure.

This game is similar to Aventura na Selva

36893.name: Batalla Aeronaval
36893.description:
This game represents a combat between a squadron of planes and a naval fleet.

The objective is to obtain 2000 points. Every successful shot turns to 50 points.

A disc is in use for determining the radar's length and allows to know the position of the shot.

Content:
- 1 Board
- 10 ships
- 10 planes
- 20 point pieces
- Radar disc

36894.name: Pile It
36894.description:
from the website

Pile it™ Card Game
A high speed flipping & sorting game

Less than 4 minutes per game

On your mark, get set...
PILE it on! Players use quick eyes and nimble fingers in a revved-up race to see who can flip and sort their cards the fastest – by color, by number, and then by picture. Packed full of speed, concentration, and competition, Pile it is full throttle fun for the entire family!

36895.name: The Office Trivia Game
36895.description:
From the manufacturer:

Based on the hit NBC-TV show starring Steve Carell, players race around the office visiting cubicles and answering questions about the adventures and misadventures of its unique characters. Includes a "Support the Rabid" rubber bracelet - as seen on the show - that players get when they win the "5K" race.

Buy Microbadge

36896.name: Disney Wheel of Fortune
36896.description:
From the manufacturer:

Combine the puzzle-solving fun of Wheel of Fortune with the magic of Disney-Pixar movies and you get a game that's entertaining for the whole family. Spin the Mickey Mouse wheel, then ask for a letter to the puzzle. Categories include: Heroes and Heroines, Villains, Movie Titles, Song Titles and more. Collect Disney dollars for uncovering letters and solving the puzzles.

36897.name: DinoX
36897.description: Based on the hit show from the BBC "Walking with Dinosaurs", this trivia game features cards with 1500 questions, 4 realistic dinosaur skeletons to assemble, and a DVD with footage from the show. Every question you answer correctly, you get to put another piece on your dinosaur skeleton. Race to be the first to complete your skeleton.

36898.name: Monopoly: Tallinn
36898.description: The Estonian version of classic Monopoly. Each block on the map represents a famous location in Tallinn, Estonia.

36899.name: Nana Shogi
36899.description:
Billed as "The World's Smallest Shogi Variant," Nana Shogi is played on a 3x3 board with two identical sets of three pieces. Rules are similar to the parent game, Shogi, but some pieces are cubes that can be promoted through a cycle of four faces taken from several other Shogi variants.

The Three Types of Pieces

A conventional Shogi king
An orthogonally-moving piece (Rook/Chariot/Swallow's Wings/Go-between)
A diagonally-moving piece (Bishop/Tile General/Cat's Sword/Dog)

36900.name: Cats At Play
36900.description:
BOX DESCRIPTION
"Chasing catnip here and there"

Unique Features:

Game allows participants to understand cat behavior.
Game requires players to be responsible for the care of their cats.
Game makes players use planning and logic to win.
Game demands participants exercise patience with their cats.
Game enables players to enjoy the companionship of cats.
Game lets contestants make both offensive and defensive moves per turn.
Game provides players with variations for more difficult games.
Game promotes cooperation and teamwork.




HAVE FUN!

GAME OBJECTIVE (from manual)
The first cat to pounce on a catnip mouse is the winner.

GAME PLAY
Players work cooperatively (cats from the same house) or against each other (different house) to catch one of two 'roaming' catnip mice. Each player first moves their cat, then moves one of the mice, each with the roll of one die.

Other variations allow for players to only move their cats with another player moving only the mice.

Obstacles include: Other cats, Dogs, Identification Tag (if missing), Fleas, Health Care (shots)

36903.description:
"Building off of the streamlined 3-D movement engine of Saganami Island Tactical Simulator, 2nd Edition, Squadron Strike lets you build any ship, from any setting, in full 3-D glory—and then pit them against each other, in titanic battles for the fate of galaxies."

"Squadron Strike takes between 5 and 10 minutes per turn with 6 ships per side, and combines fast play with more tactical depth and scalable detail than any other 'construction ready' space combat game. It’s suitable for Ages 12 and up."

"In Squadron Strike, ships move in one of three movement modes, named for the number of Newton’s Laws being obeyed; with these options you’re not stuck with whatever movement mode the game designer liked - you can pick the one that works best for the setting you’re trying to run in. You even have optional fuel rules (for both interstellar and tactical movement) to simulate the setting or TV series to whatever degree you like. You decide what reality level is appropriate for your level of fun."

"You can design nearly everything in the game, from missiles, to beams, to fighters, to torpedoes. An original setting includes pre-built ships and weapons for people who don’t want to get deeply into the customization process, but if you want it, you have complete control."

"Automated tools do complete SSD generation for you, in Excel format, or with higher end features via web applications."

"Squadron Strike comes with a complete, integrated campaign system, including web apps that automatically generate campaign maps, victory decks, and system maps. Just enter the campaign turn in the web app and the positions of the planets on the system map update automatically!"

"The boxed game will have two map sheets, a bag of tilt blocks, two bags of stacking tiles, box miniature sheets, a rulebook, an SSD book and a setting book. The ship design tools are available as a free download in Excel; the web applications (including a nicer ship design tool set, and campaign support) are behind a subscriber login."
36903.name: Squadron Strike

36904.description:
This expansion for Not Tonight Josephine comes as a standard size box of trivia questions the same size as the base game, or the more well known boxes from Trivial Pursuit. As well as new questions new rules are included for how these different format questions are used in the game.

This time instead of questions from two random categories there are four colour coded cards each corresponding, each colour corresponding to a a quarter of the board. Each card has seven questions corresponding to the categories from its section. Now you can choose to answer a non-multiple choice question from the topic directly for a chance to win a coin, or you can still treat it like the base game and draw a card with two random multiple choice questions.

Double Trouble and Quotations, the only categories that appear 4 times instead of once on the board, are treated the same as in the base game.

Expands:

Not Tonight Josephine
36904.name: Not Tonight Josephine Expansion Pack

36905.name: Eesti mälumäng
36905.description: In Eesti mälumäng you have 400 cards with 2400 questions from six categories: History, Culture, Nature, Geography, Sport and Miscellaneous. Vast majority of questions concern Estonia only. Collect a token from each category to begin your winning journey to the center square.

36906.name: Dementalism
boardgamepodcastepisode: Origins Spectacular 2015
36906.description:
Dementalism

Alright, smarty buns, here's your chance to show everyone how smart your brain is. Due to the continuing idiocy of you and your fellow security guards a whole bunch of clones have escaped from the Primordial Soup Kitchen and are now wandering the various countrysides of Mutha Oith. You guys better get your wazoos in gear and recapture them before your bosses find out and you lose your jobs.

It’ll take all of your brains, half your luck, two thirds of your charm, a bunch of guts, and a pinch of divine inspiration to survive this fast-paced and exciting original card game by award winning illustrator and game designer Andy Hopp.

Peeps: 2-12
Ages: 8+
Durations: 30-60 minutes
Contents: 128 cards, instructions, setup card, sticker

The Gist of the Thing

Security at the Primordial Soup Kitchen, that ridiculously wondrous and mythical repository of Oith’s genetic legacy, has been lax of late, to say the least. Following an insane night of fermented circuspi nut binging, impromptu (and painful) interior redecorating, and decidedly unsexy pillow fighting between you and your fellow guards you awoke from a grog-addled stupor to discover someone left the goosin’ doors open. Again.

It wouldn’t be such a bad thing under normal circumstances, but a while back the honchos decided it would be a good idea to start stockpiling clones of various important denizens of Oith (and some unimportant ones for practice). You know, in case of calamity or somesuch. Well, thanks to you and your cronies, these clones (three of each!) are now wandering the countryside, clueless and confused.

You guys should probably get your wazoos in gear and nab those hapless triplicates before they fall into the Keister of Gawd or get eaten by something. Oh, and whoever finds the most denizens doesn’t get fired or fed to anything.

The Beginning

Step 1: Gather unto thee a bunch of friends. Arrange them around a table or some other suitable playing surface.

Step 2: Take all the cards and shuffle them up really well. Then lay some of them face-down on the table in a grid 8 cards wide and 8 cards long. If your table is too small you can use a smaller grid (6 cards x 6 cards, for example). This is called the SPREAD.

Make sure each player has enough table space in front of him or her to lay a row of several cards side by side. This space, the STORE, will eventually be used to house the player’s STACKS (the cards a player collects throughout the game). Also, designate a spot somewhere on the table for the KEISTER OF GAWD (the discard pile). Set the rest of the cards facedown in a pile known heretofore as the HEAP.

Step 3: Read the rest of the rules.

Useful Terms

Cards: There are three different types of cards a peep will encounter:

Denizens represent the various peeps that escaped from the Primordial Soup Kitchen. The Spread contains three of each Denizen.

Giggities have the zazzy ability to copy the traits of other organisms. Thusly, they can form a Stack with any Denizen.

Turmoil Cards represent assorted events, catastrophes and phenomena that affect the game in various ways. Sometimes they’re good, sometimes they’re not.

Denizen Power: A special ability granted by a Safe Stack. A player may only use one Denizen Power each turn.

Flip: To turn a card face-up.

The Heap: The draw pile.

The Keister of Gawd: The Discard Pile.

Nab: To steal a Stack.

Reveal: To turn a Stack face-up. Revealed Stacks stay that way until the end of the current player’s turn, unless otherwise denoted.

Peek: To look at a Stack or card without revealing it to the others.

The Spread: The face-down grid of cards that forms the primary playing area.

Stacks: Matching cards collected throughout the game. Three types of Stacks exist. Each is worth a different amount of points.

Sneaky Stack (1 point):A Denizen and a Giggity.

Stacked Stack (2 points): Two identical Denizens.

Safe Stack (4 points): Three of the same Denizen. A Safe Stack can NEVER be discarded or nabbed by another player. That’s why it’s called a Safe Stack.

The Store: The area directly in front of each player that houses the Stacks the player has collected. Stacks in the Store are always laid from left to right in the order they were collected. Sneaky Stacks and Stacked Stacks are laid face-down, while Safe Stacks are face-up.

How to Play

The most flatulent player (by consensus) goes first. Here’s what you do on your turn:

Step 1: Flip over any one card in the Spread. If it’s a Turmoil card do what it says. If it’s a Giggity or Denizen leave it in place face-up (unless you can make a match with the Denizen).

Step 2: Flip over a second card. If it is a Turmoil card do what it says. If it’s a Denizen or a Giggity you have options:

Two Giggities: If both of the flipped cards are Giggities toss them both in the Keister of Gawd.

One Giggity & One Denizen: If one of the revealed cards is a Denizen that matches a Denizen in one of your Sneaky or Stacked Stacks you may snatch it up and insert it into the matching Stack. Adding a card to a Sneaky Stack makes it a Stacked Stack. Discard the Giggity into the Keister of Gawd. Adding a Card to a Stacked Stack makes it a Safe Stack. You may now flip it over. It can’t be stolen and you immediately have access to that Denizen’s Power (you can still only use one Denizen Power per turn, though).

If one of the revealed cards is a Denizen and the other is a Giggity you may snatch them both up and create a Sneaky Stack.

If one or more of the cards is a Denizen and you think you know where another player has a Stack that matches that Denizen you may try to steal the Stack from the other player. Point to the face-down stack in front of the other player and demand to see it. The player flips over the stack, revealing it to everyone. If you are correct, and the Denizen in the Stack matches the one you flipped, you Nab the Stack from the other player and add it to your Store. If you are incorrect, your turn ends immediately and you LOSE YOUR NEXT TURN. The owner of the wronged stack flips it back over and play continues.

Two Different Denizens: If both cards are Denizens who don’t match each other and you don’t know where a matching stack is, flip both cards back over and play passes to the next player. If one or more of the revealed cards is a Denizen that matches a Denizen in one of your Sneaky or Stacked Stacks you may snatch it up and insert it into the matching Stack (discarding the Giggity to make a Stacked Stack or combining three Denizens to make a Safe Stack.

Two Identical Denizens: If you flip two of the same Denizen you may combine them into a Stacked Stack and place it in your Store. If you already have a Sneaky Stack featuring the same Denizen you may discard the Giggity from the Sneaky Stack and combine the Denizen with the Stacked Stack to form a Safe Stack.

If you suspect another player has a Sneaky Stack featuring the flipped Denizen you may attempt to nab it as described in the previous section.

Step 3: Used Turmoil cards go to the Keister. Unmatched or undiscarded Giggities get flipped back over. Fill in any gaps in the Spread with face-down cards from the Heap. Once the Heap is depleted just leave the gaps empty.

Step 4: Your turn is over. Play progresses clockwise around the table unless a Turmoil card or Denizen Power indicates otherwise.

Sidenote: You may look at the Stacks in your own Store whenever you want, but if you do you must temporarily flip them over for everyone to see.

Denizen Powers

No doubt the observant among you have noticed a block of text at the bottom of each Denizen card. This describes the special power you can access once you have that Denizen in a Safe Stack (all three matching Denizen cards).

Each turn, once you’ve acquired one or more Safe Stacks, you may choose to initiate the power from ONE Denizen. You may activate the power at any point during your turn, but you can only use one Denizen Power per turn and you may not use the same Denizen Power two turns in a row (even if you only have one Safe Stack).

As soon as you get a Safe Stack you can access that Denizen’s Power (as long as it’s your turn and you haven’t already used a Denizen power that turn). Some Denizen Powers are activated by the actions of other players and can be used whether it’s your turn or not, as long as you haven’t already used one that turn (such as Squiggins Neverlost’s ability to avoid lost turns).
When you activate a Denizen Power turn the relevant Safe Stack the other way around (but still face-up) to signify its usage. Turn it back around at the start of your next turn.

Ending the Game

Once the Spread has been depleted and all the cards are either in the Stores or the Keister of Gawd, the game is over. Whoever has the most points, determined by the type and number of Stacks in each player’s Store, is the winner and gets to keep his or her job as a hapless minion of the Primordial Soup Kitchen. Everyone else gets fired or fed to something horrible.

In the event of a tie, whichever tieing player has the most Safe Stacks wins. If it’s still a tie the win goes to the player with the most Stacked Stacks, then the most Sneaky Stacks. If it’s still a tie after that the world blows up and nobody wins.

Stack Values

Sneaky Stack (1 Giggity & 1 Denizen): 1 Point

Stacked Stack (2 Denizens): 2 Points

Safe Stack (3 Denizens): 4 Points

36907.description: An abstract strategy game played on a circle of 12 spaces, on which white and black pieces are stacked. A piece moves as many spaces as there are pieces in the tower in which it starts, and the object is to prevent one's opponent from moving by building "blockades" five pieces high.
36907.name: Mandalay

36908.name: High 7
36908.description:
A dexterity/strategy game in which players stack wooden cuboids with the object of reaching a height of seven units. Careful use of the space and of the pieces left in hand can force the opponent to make disadvantageous moves.

Ein neues Spiel im Giseh Verlag, wie gewohnt in hochwertiger Ausführung, spannend und mit hohem Spaßfaktor für Jung und Alt! Es gilt, je nach Augenzahl der Würfel die eigenen Steine zu setzen um die siebte Ebene zu erreichen, die siegreiche Punkte birgt - jedoch ohne dem Gegner zu viel Spielraum zu lassen. Bieten Sie ihm keine Möglichkeit, die eigenen durchdachten Spielzüge für seinen Erfolg auszunutzen... eine ruhige Hand und räumliches Sehvermögen helfen bei dieser kniffeligen Herausforderung. Wer Spielsteine umwirft, hat verloren!

High begeistert Kinder und Erwachsene gleichermaßen, da es leicht zu erlernen ist und auf spielerische Weise sowohl räumliches Denkvermögen als auch haptische Fähigkeiten fördert.

36909.name: X: Die 4. Dimension
36909.description:
A four-in-a-row game on a 4×4×4 cube. The twist in this version is that each player rotates one of the levels of the cube through 90 degrees after their turn.

Similar to:

Qubic - Played on 4x4x4 cube (4x4 grid with 4 layers) but without turning layers
Score Four - 4x4 grid of pegs that are filled from the bottom up
Dimensions(1970), Hi!Noon: Das Duell(2009), and Tic Tac Turn(2011) - the 4 individual horizontal board layers (4x4 each) of the 4x4x4 grid can turn
3D5 (Cubic) - which is played on a 5x5x5 cube (5x5 grid with 5 layers) but without turning layers

36910.description:
In Oktaeder ("Octahedron") players take turns to stack one of their marbles into the playing area, building up an octahedron as the game progresses. The object is to form lines of four marbles of the player's color.

Oktaeder is similar to Kessler's game Giseh! but with an octahedral playing area instead of a pyramid. A transparent stand is provided with the game to hold the base of the octahedron during gameplay.
36910.name: Oktaeder

36911.description:
Barbarossa: The Russo-German War, 1941-45

Barbarossa is a two-player, low-to-intermediate complexity, strategic-level simulation of the entire Russo-German War designed by Ty Bomba.
36911.name: Barbarossa: The Russo-German War, 1941-45

36912.name: Askim
36912.description: This card game has 40 cards. 5 color-coded sets of 8 cards each. 4 cards in each set are question cards, 4 cards are answer cards. The object of the game is to be the first to get rid of all of your cards.

36913.name: Trail Blaze
36913.description:
Trail Blaze contains burning questions, high stakes and pot luck. Reactions may include intense rivalry, feelings of euphoria, and an increased awareness of cannabis and it's effect on your health and liberty. Trail Blaze may leave you with a clear head that persists for days, months or even years. However, taking too many risks can lead to unpleasant side effects.

Players take it in turns to roll the dice and move their counter the corresponding number of squares in the direction of the arrows.

If you land on a question square someone else must read you a question card. If you answer correctly, go forwards to the next green square. Get it wrong and go back to the last red square.

If you land on a risk square, take a risk card and follow the instructions. Return cards to the bottom of the pack.

The winner is the first player to get home.

36914.name: Suomirokkia trivia: Lisäkysymykset 2007
36914.description:
200 new question cards for Suomirokkia trivia. Also includes Genius-questions for the "real sages".

Expands:

Suomirokkia trivia

36915.name: Space, Trash, Politicians
36915.description:
This game is being revised. I wouldn't suggest playing by the posted rules. 3/30/09

The people of Earth make a lot of trash, and there's no sign this will change anytime soon. Crates full of banana peels, boxes of secondhand chicken poop, industrial mumbo-whatever, it's all here, and it needs to go somewhere. At one point, a fantastic US President said, "Let's get a big rocket..." and things progressed from there.

You are a waste removal specialist, and you want to get in on some of these contracts for sending waste into space, but where there are rockets, money, and politicians, things can get messy.

A game of bidding and risk management, with just 60 little cards.

36916.name: Gissa vad jag föreställer
36916.description: Swedish charade type game. Aimed primarily at children. The title translates roughly into "Guess what I am supposed to be".

36917.name: Forms
36917.description:
Forms is a two-players strategy game played on a square board. Initially half of the board is filled with black stones and another half of the board is filled with white stones.

A player wins if all his stones are removed from the board.

Players move alternatively by replacing any opponent's stone with an own stone taken from the board. After doing it a player removes all stones that aren't connected to the moved player's stone.

36918.name: Country Club Golf
36918.description: The object of the game is to play a round of golf in an attempt to par the course, just as you would on any golf course around the world. The game is designed to bring to some degree, the same enjoyment received in actual play. Since luck and skill are a part of each round played at your favorite golf course, luck and skill (in rolling the dice) await you as you enter the Country Club course, with its water and sand hazards.

36919.name: Imhotep
36919.description:
From the Sagacity Website:
"In the old kingdom of ancient Egypt, the pharaoh Zoser, convinced of his divinity, asked his chief architect Imhotep to design a grand tomb to house him in his afterlife. This tomb was to become known as the "stepped pyramid", the first of the great pyramids of Egypt.

Each player is a builder vying to add to their wealth through this grand project. The builders secure the services of some of the kingdom's artisans to supply finished stone for the pyramid and food for their workers. They then use these tiles to build the pyramid and are rewarded for their efforts by the treasury.

But building the pyramid is not the only way to gain wealth. There is a thriving market for the stone and food required to build the pyramid. There are profits to be made by selling goods on the open market and at times, tiles purchased on the market may let you build when you would not otherwise be able to do so. By deploying influential members of your family, you can also gain advantage in various aspects of your business dealings.

Use your money and influence wisely and the completion of the pyramid will see you take your rightful place as the kingdom's most successful builder."

36920.description:
Rules of Engagement (RoE)

This book provides gamers with all the information they need to get started with the Rules of Engagement system. Below is an outline of what the book contains, follow the link to have a look at pages from the book itself on the company website.

Rules of Engagement is a tabletop wargame for two or more players that allows you to recreate battles of the twentieth century to the present day. Players use miniature soldiers on model terrain and in this 240 page hardback book you will find a comprehensive rules system that will allow you to field your troops on the battlefield.

Game rules:
The complete gaming rules covering movement, weapons, close quarters combat, artillery and more. Includes opportunity fire, hidden troops, snipers, tank support and fortifications. With clear examples and diagrams, Rules of Engagement is easily accessible yet offers plenty of depth for experienced players.

Scenarios:
Nine scenarios from take and hold missions to desperate rearguard actions. Each scenario includes specifi c rules covering, for example, reserves, unacceptable losses and additional orders.

The Second World War 1944-45:
A detailed history of the War on Western Front from D-Day to the Fall of the Reich. The Orders of Battle section gives listings of the forces available including company and divisional support options. Forces covered: German Grenadiers, Panzergrenadiers, Volksgrenadiers, Fallschirmjäger and Waffen SS, British Infantry, Airborne and Commandos, Canadian Infantry, US Infantry, Armored Infantry, Parachute Infantry and Rangers and the Maquis.

Hobby section:
A complete colour guide to painting your miniatures and creating a battlefield. Uniform and equipment guides for all the forces featured in the Orders of Battle including British and Canadian Infantry, British Airborne and Commandos, German Grenadiers and Panzergrenadiers, Fallschirmjäger, Waffen SS and Volksgrenadiers, US Infantry, US Airborne and the Maquis.

www.greatescapegames.co.uk
36920.name: Rules of Engagement

36922.name: Kingdoms
36922.description:
Kingdoms is a card game which simulates two kingdoms or nations at war. It uses a tarot deck. The goal of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing side's cards/forces.

Full Game: http://www.gamecabinet.com/rules/Kingdoms.html

36923.name: Fantastical Factory Game
36923.description:
From the back of the box:

"Join Charlie and the other Golden Ticket winners on a fun-filled race through the Chocolate Factory!

All your fantastical favourites are here - the Chocolate Room, the Inventing Room, the Nut Room, along with the best of Mr. Willy Wonka's wonderful inventions, like Television Chocolate and the Great Gum Machine!

Each room is a game itself. Dodge the traps and the various surprises te Oompa-Loompas and squirrels have waiting along the way and be the one who wins a ride with Mr. Willy Wonka in the Great Glass Elevator!"

36924.name: Fraction Games
36924.description: This game comes with pieces of a circular pie in halves, quarters, thirds, eighths, and sixths. The basic game is to complete a playing mat in as few rolls as possible. There are 5 playing mats that show a full pie in each of the evenly distributed pie shapes (e.g. all 4 quarters). The game is intended to be educational mostly.

36925.name: Sports Pursual
36925.description: A board game in which the object of the game is to gain the most money after 3 laps of the board are completed by dice throwing, questions and gambling of money in hand.

36926.name: Bajo el Sol de África
36926.description:
Spanish skirmish game for the period of the Africa exploration between 1830 (conquest of Argel by the French) and 1925 (end of the Rif war).
The rules not only allows for historical scenarios, but also to introduce more "fantastic" elements as Tarzan, Allan Quartemain etc, or set it into a more "steam-punk" Victorian setting.
The first edition is out-of-print but there is a 2nd one published in 2008

36927.name: Bajo el Sol de África: El Libro de los Ejércitos
36927.description:
Armies list for the Spanish skirmish game "Bajo el Sol de África".
It covers both the European nations (as regular armies and local-trained troops) and the African tribes and local warlords that waged during most of the XIX century in the Dark Continent.
Included Arae Anglo-Egypcians, Askari, colonial expeditions, Arabs and Swahilis, Azande, Majdist, Masais, Zulus,...

Expands:

Bajo el Sol de África

36928.name: Zoodyssey
36928.description:
From the box:

"Zoodyssey is the only family board game that combines the fun and excitement of going to the zoo with scientific understanding of some of the world's most endangered animals.

The game takes about 55 minutes. Players move along the paths of the zoo and collect Animal Snapshot cards. Each card has a picture of a zoo animal, some Fun Facts about that animal, and a point value. The more endangered the animal, the higher the point value.

The object of the game is to be the first player with 50 points worth of Snapshot cards.

Of course it's never as easy as it sounds. A rhino may stop you. A toucan may steal one of your photos. Or you may run out of film. But nothing will stop you in your quest to add snapshots to your collection.

In the process, of course, you will come to a greater understanding of some of he magnificent creatures that share our planet. And when it is over, you'll want to set-up and play again."

36929.name: Over They Go
36929.description:
A fun party game for all the family, Ages 4 and up
The object is to build a tower as high as possible before it topples and to score points accordingly.
There are two ways to play, rules for both are printed in the box lid.
The tower is built using the ping-pong type coloured balls and the connecting tubes.

36930.name: Derek Jameson's Headliners
36930.description:
Based on the classic TV show this is a fun board game for teams to play.
The players divide into 2 teams and compete playing as The Daily Mail or The Express.
Each team has a score pad divided into 4 decades and each decade is divided into 4 categories. The object of the game is to tick off each box by the correct answering of relevant questions.
The first team to fill their card wins the game.

36931.name: Night of the Slasher
36931.description:
"Tonight the citizens of Hope County are being stalked by a merciless Slasher who will not stop until they have claimed enough victims to satisfy their sick thirst for death!

It seems that the Slasher is someone well known in the community... could it be the high school jock, the nurse, the convict, the geek or even the TV Anchorwoman?"

In this Print and Play game, each player takes on the identity of one of the 12 possible victims. One player will secretly play as the Slasher and has 8 rounds to kill all of the characters controlled by the other players.

The rest of the players must find clues to reveal the Slasher’s true identity or use weapons and other tricks to help them stay alive.

3 to 12 players can play this exciting game of strategy and suspense. Players will need to provide a 10 sided die.

This game has Adult Themes.

Night of the Slasher, the Print and Play game, can be purchased from http://www.wargamedownloads.com/item.php?item=712&;pics

boardgamehonor: 2010 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
2010 Golden Geek Best Thematic Board Game Nominee
2010 Golden Geek Most Innovative Board Game Nominee
2010 International Gamers Award - General Strategy: Two-players
2010 JoTa Best 2-Player Board Game Audience Award
36932.description:
Claustrophobia is a miniatures-based dungeon crawl game set within the universe of Hell Dorado.

The box contains pre-painted miniatures which are placed on large tiles showing the dungeon spaces. Also included are character boards, counters and markers, and dice.

One player controls a small group of determined humans, while the other plays an almost unending army of demonic creatures. The game is thematic and highly asymmetric: human characters are stronger, but the demon characters are more numerous. Gameplay is very straightforward with a minimum of rules, and each game plays in an hour or less.

In essence dice are allocated after rolling to perform actions, while cards or special abilities are also available. The game is about managing decisions and choosing what to do with the resources that you have, managing difficult events and out-thinking your opponent. Combat is handled by dice.

Complexity is low, with the focus on theme and building towards a tense, climactic ending.
Claustrophobia is played through scenarios of which there are several in the rulebook. Generally speaking the human characters are attempting to complete a task (e.g. escape the catacombs, close a portal) while the demons are focused on stopping them. There are varying win conditions depending on the scenario chosen.
36932.name: Claustrophobia
boardgamepodcastepisode: Ep 4 - Asymmetrical Games
Episode 13: The one about our top 10 2-player games
Episode 26 - The Must Play Two Player Games of 2016…as of June
Episode 37 - Our 2016 Enthusiastic Seals of Approval!
Podcast #028 - Claustrophobia y Warriors of God

36933.description:
At the outbreak of the First World War the greatest concentration of German warships outside of the North Sea was the famed East Asiatic Squadron. Winner of the Kaiser's Cup for two consecutive years, a competition testing the gunnery of His Majesty's warships, the East Asiatic Squadron was commanded by Admiral Maximilian von Spee. The East Asiatic Squadron was made up of fast and modern ships. The flagship was the Scharnhorst, a fast armoured cruiser with 8.2" guns. Her sister-ship, the Gneisenau, boasted the same specifications. In addition to these two armoured cruisers, there were the light cruisers Leipzig, Nürnberg, and Emden, all very fast and armed with 4.1" guns. This fleet provided the greatest threat to Allied shipping outside of the north Atlantic.

Spee had several options when news of the war reached him. The greatest concentration of Allied merchant shipping in the region was at the approaches to the Red Sea, where convoys from India, China, and Australia passed through the Suez Canal. But there were no places for German ships to coal in the Indian Ocean, and operating there would bring Spee into contact with the Royal Navy China Station and the powerful but slow Triumph. Operating in the northern Pacific was ruled out because of the powerful Japanese fleet, easily the largest in the Pacific. Operating around the Dutch East Indies and Australia was also discarded because it would bring the East Asiatic Squadron within the sights of the Australia, a battlecruiser with 12" guns. With few options, Spee decided to head across the Pacific where he could indirectly disrupt Allied shipping and hopefully cause enough consternation within the Royal Navy that several important ships would be detached from the Home Fleet. The south Pacific had plenty of islands from which Spee and his ships could supply and the islands also provided an effective hiding place. With luck, Spee could reach South America and coal from neutral ports there, enter the Atlantic Ocean, feast on the rich merchant shipping around Montevideo, and maybe even reach Germany.

Not all commanders concurred and the captain of the Emden proposed that his vessel would head west into the Indian Ocean where a lone ship could more easily stay hidden and coal from captured merchants. Spee agreed and the Emden sailed west while the East Asiatic Squadron sailed east, where they were expected to meet the Dresden en route from the Atlantic.

What followed was one of the greatest war time adventures at sea.

Spee eluded capture for months and appeared off the coast of Chile where he destroyed a British fleet at the Battle of Coronel. Crossing into the Atlantic, Spee was finally sunk in December 1914 under the weight of the shells from the 12" guns of the Invincible and Inflexible, two battlecruisers dispatched from North Sea waters to deal with the German threat. The Emden had an incredible campaign of her own, sinking almost two dozen merchant ships and causing panic throughout the Indian Ocean. The Emden also met a tragic end at the hands of the Sydney in November 1914.

In The Pursuit of von Spee you are put at the helm of the German or Allied fleet. Your goal as the German commander is to disrupt Allied shipping, raid Allied possessions, sink Allied warships, and survive for as long as possible. As the Allies you are to capture the German colonies and seek out and destroy the German raiders all the while trying to keep your merchant shipping en route to their destinations and afloat.

The Pursuit of von Spee is a game of deception and subterfuge. One must keep in mind at all times that the winner of this game could very well be the best bluffer. Without knowing exactly where your opponent's ships are, a subtle look could give you the hint needed to find von Spee and send his fleet to the bottom.

The Pursuit of von Spee uses a fog-of-war system that hides the location and condition of the various ships in the game. Naval combat uses a system which takes into account the size of a ship's guns, its top speed, and the strength of its armour at various parts of the ship. The Allied player has a lot of responsibilities to take care of in addition to hunting the German player, while the German player has to choose his battles carefully and keep a close eye on the condition and coal-reserves of each of his ships. The German player also has the ability to bring two other ships into the campaign, the Karlsruhe and the Königsberg. The Allied player receives reinforcements as well during the course of the game.

In your game box you will receive four 12" x 18" map sheets which join together to make one 24" x 36" map spanning from the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic. The game includes 240 mounted counters (in easy-to-cut strips), one 10-sided die, two blinds, four ship charts, five player aid sheets, and a 17-page rulebook containing all of the rules and setup information required.

This game is of medium complexity but has only a few mechanics to master. Learning the game comes quickly as the phases are simple and straight-forward. In addition to regular playtesting, this game was also play tested with a first-time wargamer, who was nevertheless able to grasp the basics of the game in her first session. Learning the strategy and intricacies of play can take much longer, as the options in this game are endless. Depending on how long von Spee survives, the game can last anywhere from 2 to 12 hours.
36933.name: The Pursuit of von Spee

36934.name: Shakeout
36934.description:
Denys Fisher had a reputation for producing some very 'different' games - not least Shakeout which involves each player taking hold of a plastic sphere filled with plastic sticks, and having to shake it frantically to 'spill' out the contents. These are then subsequently placed in various combinations upon a plastic scoreboard in a race to create the maximum points. The first Player to empty his 'sphere' and score the most is the winner!

An unusual game, and one that is so simple it is consequently overlooked.

c1971

36936.name: Slink'em
36936.description:
A "3-in-1" board game to be played with a Slinky.

The games are played on a board that folds into a ramp. The players take turns sending the Slinky down the ramp trying to land on the best squares marked on the scoring field. All squares touched are added to the score. There game came with three different boards: "Numbers Game", "Baseball Game", and "Big Game Hunt."

The board for the Numbers Game has squares marked with positive and negative numbers. The center square is normally worth 10 points. However, if the Slinky ends up in "standing position" in the center square and not touching any other square, 50 points are scored.

The Baseball and Big Game Hunt boards are marked according to their themes.

The rules folder offers a bounty of $25 for anyone offering a suggestion for the improvement of the game that is accepted and used.

36937.name: Sexy Slang's Naughty Charades
36937.description:
This is the smaller "charades only" version of the adult party game Sexy Slang. This version of Charades contains Sexy Slang terms.

The new game is marketed as the perfect inexpensive and unique gift for bachelorette parties and new brides.

The game is packaged in a small metal box and contains two card decks, 300 naughty charade terms, a naughty charades die, and a set of instructions.

36938.name: Pandarama
36938.description:
In this panda-themed game, players move along black and white squares of a game board, drawing cards with panda facts and movement directions.

This game was created by 9 year-old Amanda Wilcox along with twin sister Laura and their mother Melynda. They started working on the game when Amanda was only about eight years old. Proceeds of the game go to Washington DC's Smithsonian National Zoological Park Giant Panda Conservation Fund.

36939.name: The Road to Health
36939.description:
This educational game shows students the way to better health and physical fitness. As players move their playing pieces around the board, they are asked questions to quiz them on six categories: safety, alcohol and other drug abuse, fitness, mental health and anger management, hygiene, and nutrition.

The game comes a 20-inch wide square board, game pieces, 120 question cards and (including 12 blank cards for adding new questions), and an instructor's guide that contains rules, variations, discussion starters, a die, and a set of reproducible worksheets utilizing all of the game's questions.

36940.name: Play Rethink
36940.description:
This drawing game with an ecological twist. The players are to rethink existing, everyday products and attempt to make them more environmentally friendly. For example, a player might attempt to redesign a piece of furniture using locally sourced materials or might attempt to come up with new functions for an old piece of equipment.

The game itself is also eco-friendly. It is made in the United Kingdom using recycled and other special types of paper and vegetable-based inks along with eco-friendly laminates and other environmentally-friendly processes.

36941.name: Insel der Piraten
36941.description:
From the publisher's website:

Find the hidden treasure

Many hidden treasures wait on that secret pirate's isle. Luckily enough, the pirates have left you a treasure-map. But it is ripped in several pieces and no one knows the correct order. Each player can only look at one piece at a time. Try to find the correct location first!

Insel der Piraten - Pirate's Isle is more than a simple game of deduction. You have to draw logical conclusions to find the possible paths. Try to mark your guess first on the map and you'll be the winner. But be careful, other player can see where you're going. There are 20 adventures to solve. The game can be played with 2 to 4 player and even with a single player!

36942.name: Beat the Market
36942.description:
From the inside of the box (game description of the rules):

"This is a stock market game for 3 to 6 persons. It is played with 4 loaded (8-sided) dice called Quotes which are designed to give the effect of a constantly changing market. The black Quotes are weighted so they usually come up with low numbers and the whole Quotes are weighted so they usually come up with high numbers. Only 2 Quotes are used at a time so that a market can be low (both black), mixed (a black and a white), or high (both white). Object if ge game is to buy stock at a low price, hold it for awhile, and sell it at a higher price. The game ends when one player doubles his money or when someone goes broke. Winner is the player who first doubles his money or the player with the most money when someone goes broke. Each game lasts about an hour."

36943.name: Too many cooks
36943.description:
The game is really simple.
Each player has a plastic "fry-pan" and there is a central "stove".
The fry-pans are shaped as mazed and the stove has holes with points on them.

Players drop 1-3 balls on their fry-pans and by balancing the fry-pan aim to drop the balls on the higher value holes.

36944.description:
A fast paced game of charades.

Based on Guesstures but with different rules.

Played in teams to 15 points

The actors try to get their team to guess as many words as possible in 30 seconds (no limit).

The actor doesn't get to see the words before the timer starts but only as they come up when the timer is going.

If the actor is still trying to get the team to guess a word when they time runs out, the team loses all points gained in the round so when time is getting low, the player must decide whether to play it safe and stop or try another word and risk losing all the points earned so far this round.

After the timer runs out, the other team may challenge rules violations. If they are successful, the acting team loses all points for the round.

The electronic device has an LCD display on both sides and manages the time, the words, points and challenges. Requires three AA batteries (not included).
36944.name: Electronic Guesstures

36945.name: Chameleon
36945.description: This is a game played on a Hex board wherein the winning condition is to form a line of either color connecting your two sides. You may play either color piece on your turn.

boardgamehonor: 2009 Boardgames Australia Awards Best International Game Nominee
2009 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee
2009 Golden Geek Most Innovative Board Game Nominee
36946.description:
Red November is a cooperative game in a gnomish attack submarine where everything is going wrong. The sub is descending and the water pressure increasing, the nuclear reactor is overheating, the nuclear missile launchers are pre-igniting, fires and water leaks are everywhere, there's a giant Kraken looming nearby and there’s very little oxygen and vodka left. While the storyline feels more and more like a disaster movie, the players must get organized to solve the problems, divide the tasks among themselves to minimize the risks, and sometimes accept to sacrifice themselves for the common cause.

The game is played on the map of the submarine. The conditions in the submarine are represented by three disaster tracks: Asphyxiation, Heat and Pressure. During the game, these conditions get worse, and if anyone of them reaches its maximum value, the submarine is lost. In addition, various emergencies can occur which have to be dealt with swiftly, or they'll also lead to the loss of the submarine.

Each turn, a player can move to a new location, and perform some action there. Such an action can be repairs (which will improve conditions on the sub and/or fix emergencies), removing obstacles (unblocking hatches, removing flooding or extinguishing fires) or stocking up on equipment (which will help with later actions). Each action is paid for with time. The more time a player spends on an action, the greater the chance of success. After each player's turn, a number of events will happen; the more time was spent, the more events will occur. Such events will be the worsening of conditions in the submarine, or the triggering of emergencies.

If the Gnomes can keep alive long enough, rescue will arrive and the game is won.
36946.name: Red November
boardgamepodcastepisode: 1P 088 - Red November and puzzle games
OBG 34: Bait Games
The Messy Game Room Episode 2
The Spiel #68 - That's A Wrap - 2008 Holiday Gift Guide
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 81
WIPNcast 091

36947.name: Aztekz
36947.description:
From the publisher's website:

Free the lost souls!

Lots of lost souls wander around the old Aztec's pyramid. As a chief, you have to earn your right to rest in that pyramid. Free as many souls as you can to obtain your last sleep's place.

Each player has a chief and two slaves. The chief moves very slowly but can steal collected souls from other player's slaves. The slaves are fast and can collect souls to bring them to their chief. But the pyramid's maze is changing with every turn and your just-so-well-constructed escape-way is not blocked. Keep cool, because the more souls you deliver to your chief at once, the more score. But be warned: If you're too greedy, it may be over too fast and you'll end up with nothing.

Aztekz is a very complex collecting-game with very simple rules and a lot of strategic possibilities. Quick to learn, always tricky and challenging.

36948.name: Shellz
36948.description:
From the publisher's website:

The tricky quest for shiny seashells

Compete against other players in search for the most valuable seashells. Build a path that leads to the longest rows of shells to get massive points. Use your branches and curves, build over other cards to cut-off the others path. With the right card you can even dig-out other cards. Place your pawn wisely to get double score. If you manage to connect to paths together, you may even get the other player's score. With three cards on hand you can plan your path carefully, but still the other players may manipulate your path. Also take care not to concentrate on certain kinds of shells only, since the lower scored-shells also count at the end. The war goes off at the middle of the gameboard, it's getting crowded there! Will you stay cool?

Shellz is a tricky building-game. You sometimes have to "think around the corner". Don't let the beautiful shells distract you - it's a tough game for big brains.

For 2 to 4 players Ages 10 and up, 30 - 45 minutes playing time. English instructions included.

36949.name: Maternal Generations
36949.description:
(from the rulebook) Maternal Generations is a quick 2 player card game of strategy. Compete against an opponent to build up maternal "family lines" while considering the best moment to disprove your opposing lines.

Genealogy family lines are built as the player uses the research ability of cards in their hand to get cards from the "gene pool" on the table. Then the player plays one card from their hand to their family line each turn, by placing a higher number card each turn. When you are unable to play on existing family lines, they must start new ones, but only lines of 4 or more cards will score points. Be careful to build lines that score enough points and are safe against the other player's disprove action.

The game contains 34 ancestor cards, 1 wild records search card, and a color illustrated manual.

36950.name: The Ancient Pirates of Pernia
36950.description:
Ancient Pirates of Pernia is a fantasy / strategy board game for ages 8 to adult that will provide hours of enjoyment! It involves ancient weaponry prior to widespread gunpowder use. Pirates will attack with ancient siege type weapons and swords to take cargo and plunder.

Game comes in a large "bag" and contains 8 sided Dice, and Directional Pirate Dice, Ship & Game Boards, Marker Clips for 1 to 4 players, & 50 Cards of; Action, Crew, Weapon and Cargo.

36952.description: A vintage children's race track game about searching for mushrooms. The instructions are in German. The game is played on a colorful gameboard with a fairy tale style fantasy painting of little people among a variety of mushrooms (both edible and poisonous varieties) that are growing in a forest. The game board has numbered points corresponding to the different mushrooms and characters on the game board. A set of cardboard markers are used in the game.
36952.name: Pilzsuchen

36953.description:
Barons to Kings is a tile laying game where players build roads to gain movement and capture markets to earn needed funds. Players build fleets and walls to protect their property while trying to avoid other players and the plague. Battle takes place with cards and dice.
Each player picks a flag on one of the 4 corners of the game board. This spot will be their starting point for every move they make. Gold tile pieces represent various coinage of the age. Gold tiles are the only way to buy new Military, Road & Wall pieces from the center pile which you will need to survive. The only way to get more gold is to get a military unit to one of the Market Squares in the middle of the board & hold it.
Once your empire is built, you will expand towards the other players and begin to conquer.
36953.name: Barons to Kings

36954.name: Americaopoly
